children.name: glorify
children.definition: to make sb or sth seem much better, less harmful etc than they really are – used when you think it is wrong to do this: tôn vinh
examples: His films glorify violence.
My father never glorified war.
These images were produced in order to glorify the empire.
films which glorify violence
glorification[U]
the glorification of war

children.name: exaggerate
children.definition: to say that something is much bigger, better, worse, more important etc than it really is: phóng đại

children.name: it is difficult/hard/impossible to exaggerate sth
children.definition: used to say that something cannot be made to seem more important etc than it already is
examples: It is difficult to exaggerate the strength of people’s feelings on this matter.

children.name: it is easy to exaggeratesth
examples: It’s all too easy to exaggerate the importance of these rather minor factors.

children.name: exaggerate the importance/significance
children.definition: ofsth
examples: Personally, I think society exaggerates the importance of marriage.

children.name: exaggerate the extent of sth
children.definition: say that the size or degree of something is greater than it really is
examples: The army exaggerated the extent to which the operation was a success.

children.name: exaggerate the impact
children.definition: ofsth
examples: (= say the effect or influence of something is worse than it really is )We believe the Chancellor is exaggerating the impact these proposals will have.

children.name: exaggerate the size
children.definition: of sth
examples: I’m sure Tommy is exaggerating the size of the problem.

children.name: exaggerate the effect
children.definition: of sth
examples: He yawned widely, exaggerating the effect by stretching his arms wide.

children.name: ‘He said you walked 30 miles.’ ‘No - he’s exaggerating. It was only about 15.’
examples: Newspapers tend to exaggerate their influence on the way people vote.
The grass in the garden was about three feet high - I’m not exaggerating.
I couldn’t sleep for three days – I’m not exaggerating.

children.name: it’s easy/difficult/impossible to exaggerate sth
examples: It’s difficult to exaggerate the importance of sleep.

children.name: talk up
children.definition: to talk about sth in a way that makes it appear more important, interesting, or successful than it really is, especially to get sb’s support or interest:
examples: At the interview, he talked up his experience of working in sales.
The government tried to talk up the threat posed by these countries, in order to justify an increase in military spending.

children.name: blow sth out of all proportion
children.definition: blow sth (up) out of all proportion to say that a situation or event is a lot worse or much more serious than it really is, especially with the result that people become very worried or annoyed: thổi phồng lên
examples: The whole thing has been blown out of all proportion by the media.
It was just a simple disagreement. Don’t blow it up out of all proportion.

children.name: make too much of
children.definition: to treat sth that has happened as though it were more important or serious than it really is – used especially when saying that you should not do this: làm quá
examples: The press made too much of his stupid remark. He was only joking.
She loved the fact that he’d sent her flowers, but she didn’t want to make too much of it in case it meant nothing.

children.name: overemphasize
children.definition: / overemphasiseUK  to say that a part of sth is more important than it really is, especially in relation to other things: cường điệu
examples: The report overemphasizes the role of the teacher. Children also learn from their parents and from each other.
The importance of strict hygiene in the preparation of food cannot be overemphasized.

children.name: overstate
children.definition: to describe sth in a way that makes it sound more important or serious than it really is, especially in order to persuade people about sth: phóng đại, cường điệu
examples: The company says that the dangers of driving while using cell phones have been overstated.
Politicians typically overstate their case in order to get their point across.
The importance of advertising can hardly be overstated.

children.name: overstate your case
examples: Sometimes sheoverstates her case.

children.name: be melodramatic
children.definition: behaving as if a situation is much worse or more serious than it really is, especially with the result that you seem silly: làm quá
examples: Oh, don’t be so melodramatic! You’re not the only one who has ever failed an exam.
She said she’d kill herself if he left her. She’s always so melodramatic!

children.name: lay it on
children.definition: to say that your situation is much worse or you feel much more upset than is really true, in order to make sb feel sorry for you: thổi phồng
examples: She really laid it on - saying that her kids would starve if we didn’t give you a job.

children.name: lay it on thickthổi phồng quá mức
examples: Most charities lay it on so thick it’s hard to know what the truth is.

children.name: overplay
children.definition: to make sth seem more important than it is, in the way that you talk about it or treat it: OPP underplay:quan trọng hóa
examples: His role in the group’s success has been overplayed.
The media has greatly overplayed this issue.

children.name: overrate
children.definition: to have too good an opinion of something:
examples: Be careful not to overrate the opposition.

children.name: idealized
children.definition: an idealized image, view, picture etc of sb or sth shows them as being much better than they really are: lý tưởng hóa
examples: His books give an idealized picture of English rural life.

children.name: her friend’s idealized view of marriage
exaggeration
children.definition: a statement or way of saying something that makes something seem better, larger etc than it really isOPP understatement: thổi phồng cường điệu phóng đại
examples: It would be an exaggeration to say that we were close friends.
The situation can be described, without exaggeration, as disastrous.

children.name: a great exaggeration
children.definition: by a large amount
examples: To suggest that the company is facing bankruptcy is a great exaggeration.

children.name: a gross exaggeration
children.definition: very great and untrue
examples: The figures in this report are a gross exaggeration.

children.name: a wild exaggeration
children.definition: an extreme exaggeration that is not at all realistic
examples: He claims to be 120 years old, but that's is clearly a wild exaggeration.

children.name: a slight exaggeration
children.definition: small
examples: I think that saying the animals are almost extinct is a slight exaggeration.

children.name: be a bit of an exaggerationinformal
children.definition: be a slight exaggeration
examples: It's a bit of an exaggeration to say he's handsome.

children.name: it's no exaggeration to say that ...
children.definition: used to emphasize that something is really true
examples: It's no exaggeration to say that residents live in fear of the local gangs.

children.name: without exaggeration
children.definition: telling the truth and not exaggerating
examples: The men spoke without exaggeration about their ordeal.

children.name: sb is prone to exaggeration
children.definition: somebody often exaggerates
examples: At that age, children are prone to exaggeration.

children.name: it is an exaggeration to say that
examples: It is an exaggeration to say that he earns more money than anyone I know, but he is certainly very well paid.
Itwould benoexaggerationtosay that her work has saved lives.
It isno exaggerationto say that everyone will be affected by the new policy.

children.name: exaggerated
children.definition: making sth seem much worse, better, more important etc than it really is:
examples: The numbers killed in the massacre are probably exaggerated.

children.name: greatly/highly exaggerated
children.definition: by a large amount
examples: The union put the figure at 5,000, but we believe this has been greatly exaggerated.

children.name: vastly exaggerated
children.definition: by a very large amount
examples: Bates told the children vastly exaggerated stories of his wartime exploits.

children.name: grossly exaggerated
children.definition: by a very large amount, and in a way that is wrong
examples: The damage the animals did to crops was grossly exaggerated.

children.name: wildly exaggerated
children.definition: by a very large amount, in a way that is not at all realistic
examples: Wildly exaggerated reports began appearing in the press.

children.name: slightly exaggerated
examples: Roger spoke with a slightly exaggerated American accent.

children.name: deliberately exaggerated
children.definition: in a way that is intended or planned
examples: She blinked twice in a deliberately exaggerated gesture of surprise.

children.name: extravagant
children.definition: exaggerated a lot and therefore difficult to believe: quá mức
examples: Extravagant claims have been made for some herbal remedies including the curing of baldness.

children.name: overstatement
children.definition: a statement that is exaggerated and therefore probably not true - use this especially as a polite way of saying that a statement is exaggerated: cường điệu
examples: He said she was really beautiful -- a slight overstatement I thought.
To say the company was going bankrupt is an overstatement. We have one or two financial problems, that’s all.

children.name: It’s an overstatement to
examples: It’s an overstatement to say that the man’s a fool.

children.name: underplay
children.definition: to make sth seem less important or less serious than it really is: xem nhẹ, coi thường
examples: She underplays her achievements.

children.name: play down
children.definition: topretendthat a problem, illness etc is less important or serious than it really is: coi nhẹ, xem nhẹ
examples: The government is trying to play down the seriousness of the unemployment figures.
The plan will cause a lot of changes, but officials are trying to play it down.

children.name: play down the importance/seriousness/significance of sth
examples: The White House spokeswoman sought to play down the significance of the event.

children.name: belittle
children.definition: to say or do something that makes sb’seffortsorachievementsseem unimportant or useless: xem thường (ảnh hưởng , thành tích của ai)
examples: Good teachers never belittle their students.
Does your boss constantly belittle your contribution to the department?
He tends to belittle her efforts.

children.name: understate
children.definition: to describe the size, value, or importance of sth in a way that makes it seem less than it really is: xem nhẹ
examples: I think you are understating the importance to young people of a stable home life.
In the report, the incidence of violent crime is consistently understated.
She believes the research understates the amount of discrimination women suffer.

children.name: trivialize
children.definition: /trivialiseUK  to write or talk about sth in a way that makes it seem less serious or important than it really is – used to show disapproval: tầm thường hóa
examples: The newspaper’s headlines trivialized the war, making it seem like a game.
Judges feared that showing the trial on television would trivialize the legal process.
The article trivializes the whole issue of equal rights.
The debate has been trivialized by the media.

children.name: downplay
children.definition: topretendthat a problem, illness etc is less important or serious than it really is: coi nhẹ, xem nhẹ
examples: He accused drug companies of downplaying the risks of the new drug.
She downplayed any suggestion that there had been a leak in the chemical factory.
White House officials attempted to downplay the President’s role in the affair.

children.name: make little of sth
children.definition: make little ofsthto not consider sth to be very important
examples: He made little of his ordeal.

children.name: talk down
children.definition: to talk about sth in a way that makes it seem less important or less serious than it really is
examples: He began his lecture by talking down the initiatives of a rival company.

children.name: underrate
children.definition: to fail to understand how skilful, important, etc. someone or something is
examples: The company has consistently underrated the importance of a well-trained workforce.

children.name: underratedadjective
examples: In my opinion, fennel is an underrated vegetable - few people realize how delicious it is.

children.name: understatement
children.definition: a statement that is not strong enough to express how good, bad, impressive etc something really is: lời nói giảm nhẹ
examples: To say the movie was badis an understatement.
To say that her resignation was a shock would be an understatement - it caused panic.
the understatement of the year/ month/ etc.
That New York City is not a peaceful place to live is the understatement of the year/month/century.

children.name: ‘It wasn’t very easy to find the house.’ ‘That’s got to bethe understatement of the year!’
go overboard
examples: to do something too much, or to be too excited or eager about something_I don't suppose there'll be more than six people eating so I wouldn't go overboard with the food.
